items.title: Fossil fuel phaseout plan dropped from draft UN climate deal
items.summary_auto:
The UN climate summit was headed for a showdown on Friday over the future of fossil fuels, after host Brazil dropped 
efforts to develop a global plan to shift away from oil, gas and coal from its proposed deal.

items.title: What's behind the spike in jewelry store smash-and-grabs in Ontario
Donation of Second World War grenade prompts Ontario thrift store evacuation
items.summary_auto: A Second World War grenade prompted the closure of a Chatham-Kent thrift store Thursday afternoon, police said.

items.title: A new law gives Ontario more power over school boards. What does Bill 33 mean for your family?
Pilot killed as Indian fighter jet crashes at Dubai Air Show
items.summary_auto: An Indian HAL Tejas crashed Friday local time while flying a demonstration flight for a crowd at the Dubai Air Show, sending black smoke over the Maktoum International Airport in the Emirates. It wasn't immediately clear if the pilot ejected the aircraft.

items.title: Does Alexa understand your toddler? Western University researchers are looking into it
items.summary_auto: Two researchers at Western University in London, Ont., are studying how to improve the way artificial intelligence understands toddlers' speaking patterns. They're recruiting preschool-age children to examine how they speak and use that data to train an AI model.

items.title: N.L. family fights admissions process to MUN’s medical school, says it discriminates against military members
items.summary_auto: For Rebecca McDonald, it’s long been a dream to study medicine, become a doctor and practise at home — in Newfoundland and Labrador. But while pursuing that dream, she’s hit an unexpected roadblock — the question of whether or not she’s a resident of the province.

items.title: Poland rail explosion shows Europe still struggling to respond to Russia’s shadow war
items.summary_auto: When Poland announced that an explosion damaged a railway track leading to Ukraine this week, Prime Minister Donald Tusk was quick to declare it was an unprecedented act of sabotage designed to cause catastrophe.

items.title: Mexico City plans exhumation of 6,600 bodies in search for disappeared
items.summary_auto: Mexico City began a project this week to exhume and identify thousands of bodies from an area of common graves in a municipal cemetery as part of a multi-agency strategy to deal with its growing list of people registered as disappeared.

items.title: Trump's G20 boycott could make room for Canada to advance other trade talks
items.summary_auto: Prime Minister Mark Carney is headed to the G20 in South Africa where there could be more space to try and advance trade talks with other countries because U.S. President Donald Trump isn't attending.

items.title: Serial killer Dellen Millard, who murdered Tim Bosma, Laura Babcock, moved to medium security prison
items.summary_auto: Serial killer Dellen Millard has been moved from a maximum-security prison to a medium-security facility in Ontario, CBC News has learned.

items.title: Is pharmacare on ice? Health minister says no new deals with provinces in the works
items.summary_auto: Canada’s public drug insurance program appears to be in limbo, with the Carney government failing to earmark any new money to expand coverage to the rest of the country.

items.title: China might be winning the AI race. Does it matter?
items.summary_auto: A Beijing company recently released China's smartest artificial intelligence model yet — narrowing the gap between that country and the U.S. in a race that some have likened to a new cold war.

items.title: Roughly 500,000 Canadians left ERs before seeing a doctor last year, data shows
items.summary_auto: About half a million people left emergency departments across Canada before being seen by a doctor last year, according to data analysis by CBC’s Marketplace.

items.title: Why Canada is winning the travel trade war with the U.S.
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump’s divisive politics, tariffs and heightened border security have helped drive a decline in international tourism spending in the U.S. Meanwhile, polls and industry experts suggest a surge of Canadian patriotism and perceptions of Canada as a safe and friendly destination helped drive a record-breaking summer for tourism in the country.

items.title: What's the best way to improve access to psychologists in Canada?
items.summary_auto: The number of hours needed to start working as a psychologist seeing patients in Ontario could be slashed under proposed changes aimed at boosting the province's supply of the health professionals.

items.title: #TheMoment Haiti qualified for first World Cup in over 50 years
items.summary_auto: Paul Toussaint, a Haitian chef in Montreal, tells The National about the moment he watched his home country make it to the World Cup for the first time since 1974.

items.title: 11 injured, 4 seriously, in grizzly bear attack on school kids on B.C.'s Central Coast
items.summary_auto: Two people are in critical condition and two others are seriously injured after a reported grizzly bear attack in Bella Coola on British Columbia’s Central Coast, according to emergency officials.

items.title: $54.7M US sale of Frida Kahlo self-portrait shatters auction record for female artists
items.summary_auto: A 1940 self-portrait by famed Mexican artist Frida Kahlo sold Thursday for $54.7 million US ($77 million Cdn) at a New York art auction and became the top sale price for a work by any female artist.

items.title: At Issue | Will there be fallout from the budget vote?
items.summary_auto: At Issue: The Liberals get their budget passed, but will there be fallout from the vote? Alberta’s push for a pipeline and exemptions to B.C.’s oil tanker ban. And U.S. ambassador Pete Hoekstra says restarting trade talks ‘won’t be easy.’

items.title: Actor Kevin Spacey says he's living out of hotels after losing Hollywood roles
items.summary_auto: Several men accused Spacey of making unwanted sexual advances during the #MeToo movement. In an interview with The Telegraph, Spacey said the financial hardship that followed has left him without a permanent home. While none of the allegations were proven in court, Spacey says the allegations have kept Hollywood at bay.

items.title: The Fugees' Pras Michel handed 14-year sentence for illegal donations to Obama re-election campaign
items.summary_auto: Grammy-winning rapper Prakazrel (Pras) Michel of the Fugees was sentenced on Thursday to 14 years in prison for a case in which he was convicted of illegally funnelling millions of dollars in foreign contributions to Barack Obama's 2012 re-election campaign.

items.title: 'Quiet, piggy': As Trump berates female reporters, what's the breaking point?
items.summary_auto: It's certainly not the first time U.S. President Donald Trump has insulted a female reporter, but calling Bloomberg's Catherine Lucey 'piggy' on Air Force One, then berating ABC News' Mary Bruce a few days later has raised questions about just how much journalists are expected to tolerate as they do their jobs.

items.title: Video showing mishandling of a dead body in Quebec City prompts coroner's investigation
items.summary_auto: The Quebec coroner's office has launched an internal investigation after a video circulated online showing a funeral transporter inappropriately moving a body.

items.title: U.K. government moves to ban inflated resale of tickets for entertainment and sports events
items.summary_auto: The U.K. government announced that it is banning the resale of concert, sports, and live event tickets above face value. Fans there could be saved from shelling out around $206 million annually for tickets.

items.title: Trump administration touts plan for new oil drilling off California, Florida
items.summary_auto: The Trump administration announced on Thursday new oil drilling off the California and Florida coasts for the first time in decades, advancing a project that critics say could harm coastal communities and ecosystems, as U.S. President Donald Trump seeks to expand U.S. oil production.

items.title: Alberta aims to curtail regulatory bodies from sanctioning workers for after-hours activities
items.summary_auto: Many Alberta workers could no longer be investigated by their licensing bodies for what they say outside of work hours, should the legislature pass a new bill.

items.title: Democratic vets in Congress warn about following unlawful military orders, which Trump calls seditious
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump has lashed out at six congressional Democrats who this week released a video to social media advising troops they can decline unlawful orders, branding it seditious behaviour.

items.title: Warner Music and Udio settle lawsuit, agree to build new AI music platform
items.summary_auto: The deal settles Warner's copyright infringement claims against AI music generation platform Udio, and will allow the platform to train its AI on licensed and authorized music from its artists. This agreement closely mirrors one signed weeks ago between Udio and Universal Music Group, and comes as AI generated songs and artists have been increasingly popping up on streaming platforms and rising on music charts.

items.title: Fire disrupts UN climate talks
items.summary_auto: Fire disrupted United Nations climate talks in Brazil on Thursday, forcing evacuations of several buildings and delaying already sluggish negotiations by most of a day with no major agreements even close. Officials said 13 people were treated for smoke inhalation.

items.title: Bell slashes nearly 700 jobs in latest round of layoffs
items.summary_auto: Bell Canada says it's cutting about 690 employees, mostly managers, to help reduce debt and drive growth. The cuts follow thousands of company layoffs last year.
